metadata.title: Cri du chat Syndrome
anatomical location body part affected: Many systems may be affected in cri du chat syndrome, including the brain and the skeletal, cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, and respiratory systems(1,2)
description: Cri du chat syndrome (CdCS) is a genetic disorder in which an infant presents with a high-pitched  cry, microcephaly (small head circumference), delayed communication development, broad nasal bridge, epicanthal folds (folds of skin in the inner eye corners), abnormal dermatoglyphics (e.g., fingerprints, palm prints), severe psychomotor deficits, and, often, intellectual disability.(1,2,3) Behavioral characteristics of CdCS include self-injurious  behavior, obsessive attachment to objects, hyperacusis (hypersensitivity to sound), stubbornness, and clumsiness.(4) Neonatal problems include low birth weight, asphyxia (inability to breathe), cyanotic crises (bluish color of skin due to deoxygenated hemoglobin), impaired sucking ability, and hypotonia (low tone).(3) Recurrent respiratory and intestinal infections are also common in infancy. The following malformations often are present: cardiac, neurological, and renal abnormalities; preauricular tags (small skin tag in front of ear); syndactyly (e.g., fused fingers); hypospadias (abnormally placed urinary meatus); and cryptorchidism (absence of one or both testes from the scrotum)(3)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Communication abilities of patients with CdCS vary from person to person and are influenced by the patient’s age, the severity of the patient’s motor impairment, the presence or absence of a vision or hearing loss, and/or the degree of cognitive impairment. Speech production is characterized by substitutions, omissions and distortions, limited consonant speech sound inventories, restricted syllable shapes, variable vowel production, and reduced ability to sustain phonation.(5) Individuals with CdCS have severely delayed expressive language skills and reduced mean length of utterance (MLU) and vocabulary. Cognitive abilities range from average ability to severely impaired(6) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Patients with CdCS have complex and varied medical conditions, including, but not limited to, cardiovascular conditions, respiratory conditions, sleep disturbances, gastrointestinal conditions, inattention, hyperactivity, and self-injurious  behaviors.(1) The speech-language  pathologist (SLP) should be aware of the exact nature of the patient’s medical condition before initiating assessment or treatment

causes: CdCS is a genetic disorder that results from the deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5 (5p-).(3) Incidence estimatesrange from 1 in 15,000 to 1 in 50,000 live births(3)–Genetic inheritance (10–15%  familial translocations)(1)–Mutation of the egg or sperm (de novo deletion) with no known risk factors(3)
pathogenesis: CdCS is caused by gene mutation or inheritance of a genetic translocation(1,3)

overall contraindications precautions: The symptoms associated with CdCS vary significantly, and precautions will vary according to the individual patient and the severity of accompanying language, cognitive, cardiac, and/or motor impairments. CdCS is usually diagnosed in infants; therefore, evaluation precautions will also be determined by the patient’s age and family concerns. It is recommended that parents and/or caregivers be involved in all assessment procedures due to the typical age of patient at diagnosis and the degree of intellectual disability associated with this syndrome. In addition, family priorities for treatment should be considered when deciding upon assessment procedures(7)

A patient’s medical records should be reviewed thoroughly prior to the evaluation. During the evaluation, it is of utmost importance to be aware of a patient’s level of attention, fatigue, and frustration

Development of an individualized family service plan (IFSP) or an individual education plan (IEP) in collaboration with the parents and school personnel is essential for children with CdCS to address learning, language, and cognitive problems as well as feeding and motor problems in the home and school environment. In addition, such a plan can assist school personnel in modifying activities that might otherwise be harmful or unsafe for the child
Hyperactivity and distractibility are common among persons with CdCS and can adversely affect test performance(3)

A patient’s family, culture, and native language should also be considered to determine the appropriateness of examination questions and materials. In addition, assessment data from multiple settings should be gathered to determine the influence of contextual factors on functioning (e.g., NICU, clinic, home)(8)
It is particularly important to include an assessment of the child in a “natural environment” (e.g., a familiar room in school/ daycare, at the child’s house)(8)

When evaluating very young children, patients with severe communication impairments, patients with significant motor impairments, or patients with cognitive impairments, standardized assessment measures may need to be supplemented or replaced by nonstandardized, parent interview, and observation-based  methods(8)
If a patient uses an AAC device, those systems and/or other preferred modes of communication should be made available during a communication assessment(8)

course of treatment.medical management: Document all previous and current medical management
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken? The concurrent use of multiple medications is common among children who have complex medical conditions, and the side effects of these medications may adversely affect cognitive and communicative functioning. Contact a pharmacist or physician regarding questions about medication interactions and side effects
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
Diagnosis of CdCS is made by a physician based on the presence of characteristic physical features (e.g., facial
dysmorphism, transverse flexion creases, hypotonia and "catlike"  cry) and a karyotype analysis(3,9)
Diagnosis can be further confirmed by a genetic specialist by FISH (fluorescence in situ hybridization) for a precise diagnosis of the 5p deletion(3)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies (e.g., special diet) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational, physical, or speech-language  therapy for this or for other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Speech and language symptoms of CdCS are variable and are influenced by the patient’s age, the severity of the patient’s motor impairment, the presence or absence of a vision or hearing loss, and/or the degree of cognitive impairment -sound substitutions, omissions, and distortions(10) -small consonant inventories(10) -restricted syllable shapes(10) -variable vowels(10) -reduced ability to sustain phonation(5) -extremely reduced language with shortened sentence length and limited vocabulary(10) -better receptive than expressive language(10) -cognitive abilities can range from normal intellectual abilities to severe intellectual deficits(6) -hearing and vision deficits(10) -short attention span(10) -hyperactivity(10) -stereotyped aggressive or self-injurious  behaviors(10)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document any abnormalities in the patient’s sleep patterns. Patients with CdCS often have atypical sleep patterns that can be challenging for school schedules and for caregivers’ sleep routines.(1) In a case-control  study conducted in the Netherlands, researchers found that snoring was a common feature of sleep disturbances in children with CdCS and other syndromes associated with intellectual disability(30)

history of present illness.respiratory status: Document any respiratory difficulties of patientDocument psychosocial status and behaviors that might necessitate referral to a behavioral specialist. Patients with CdCS can be very friendly and affectionate, with happy dispositions; however, these patients also sometimes engage in self-stimulatory,  self-injurious,  or aggressive behavior(1,11) -In a study conducted in the United Kingdom with 19 children with CdCS (as well as 19 children with Angelman syndrome [AS] and 15 children with Cornelia de Lange syndrome [CdLS]), researchers found that significantly more participants with either AS (18/19) or CdLS (15/15) scored above the cutoff for autism spectrum disorder (ASD) (as measured by the Social Communication Questionnaire [SCQ], previously known as the Autism Screening Questionnaire) than children with CdCS (12/19).(31) Communication skills of the participants with CdCS that were used to initiate social interaction were much less impaired and were used more frequently than in the participants with the other two diagnoses.(31) Individuals with CdCS in the study scored higher than children with the other two diagnoses for motivation for interaction with familiar adults (i.e., the children with CdCS were highly motivated to interact with familiar adults)(31) -Families of children with CdCS have reported high levels of stress resulting from the presence of maladaptive behaviors. relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Document the presence of any characteristic facial features that are associated with CdCS, including facial dysmorphism and malocclusion
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: While conducting an augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) assessment, an SLP should observe a patient’s posture and fine and gross motor skills. Patient use of any adaptive and/or orthotic equipment should be noted (e.g., hearing aids, wheelchair). The ways in which AAC will support the patient’s participation in activities of daily living should be considered. As part of an ongoing assessment, the patient should be given access to a range of AAC systems for trial in controlled and natural contexts(8)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Document the results of audiological testing and ensure that the patient has had an audiological evaluation prior to a communication evaluation. Many patients with CdCS have been reported to have a hearing loss(1,3,7)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Test protocols and tasks can be used to further explore the language skills of patients with CdCS; however, given the multiple physical and cognitive disabilities associated with CdCS, scores from standardized speech and language tests will not be valid. Examples of tests to examine speech and language skills in children with CdCS(10)(20) Measures receptive and expressive language skills in children aged 1 to 6;11 years(21) Measures English vocabulary for individuals aged 2 to 18 years(22) Measures receptive vocabulary in standard English for ages 2.5 to 90 years(23) Measures communication skills with norm-referenced  parent checklists for children 8 months to 30 months old(24) Measures developmental skills and behaviors gross motor, fine motor, social, and self-help(25) Measures communication skills in infants and toddlers
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Document the mode(s) of communication used at home and in the educational setting (if applicable). Patients with CdCS exhibit variation in their communication development, but all have delayed speech and language development. Some patients will communicate by gesture, sign language, or using AAC while others can communicate in single words or short multiword sentences. Some patients with CdCS never develop spoken language.(10) Receptive language skills have been noted to be stronger than expressive language skills(10)Patients with CdCS often exhibit articulation that is imprecise and sometimes unintelligible.(10) Substitutions, omissions, and distortions of consonants and vowels are frequent. Consonant inventories and syllable shapes are restricted and vowels are variable.(10,13)Because articulation skills can be so impaired, some researchers have noted that nonverbal communication skills (e.g., facial expression) are a relative strength for patients with CdCS.(31) Articulation skills can be assessed using standardized assessments and/or by obtaining and analyzing a speech sample. The speech sample may have to be restricted to the elicitation of functional words that the child knows due to a reduced  vocabulary and lack of spontaneous utterances.(14) For some young, shy children, documentation of a consonant inventory might rely on parent report -In a study conducted in Norway with 8 children with CdCS (ages 4;6 to 12;3), researchers examined consonant production and speech intelligibility of these children.(32) To elicit consonant productions, researchers utilized a noun elicitation task; the stimuli for each child were not the same because of the heterogeneity of the sample, but researchers chose target words that elicited consonant productions in the initial, medial, and final positions. In this sample of children, all spoke an eastern variety of Norwegian except 1 child, who spoke a southern dialect of Norwegian. All elicitations were recorded and transcribed to evaluate articulation errors and estimate intelligibility. Analysis of speech samples revealed extensive variation in consonant inventories as well as speech intelligibility. Of the 8 children in the study, 1 was rated as “high” for speech intelligibility, 2 as “medium,” and 5as “low.” Researchers also noted that labial stops were present for all children, and rhotic sounds and sibilants occurred infrequently(32)Document the presence or absence of echolalia or any other repetition of words, phrases, or sounds. Echolalia is common among patients with CdCS(4,11)Assess the patient’s receptive and expressive language skills using standardized language tests or language sampling, as appropriate. The impact of cognitive and motor impairments on a patient’s ability to respond to test questions should be taken into consideration. Language sampling, parent report, and observation of play might be the most helpful language assessment procedures for children with CdCS. Language of children with CdCS has been characterized as having a reduced mean length of utterance (MLU), a high percentage of one-word  utterances, a large number of word omissions, incorrect word order, and use of rote phrases.(15) Expressive language skills are usually weaker than receptive language skills; however, there is also great variability among individuals -Authors of a case study of a child with CdCS indicated that in this child a small portion of utterances were complex and there was considerable lexical diversity(15) -Authors of a case study of a 14-year-old  Norwegian child with CdCS found that although her phonological and syntactic skills were poor, she had mastered some aspects of morphology. She inflected words of different classes with 98% accuracy in obligatory contexts, and the errors she did make were incorrect gender in nominal forms of the word and occasional use of inaccurate verb form. In a past-tense  elicitation task, however, the child performed poorly and her score was worse than what would have been expected from a typically developing 4-year-old  learning Norwegian(16)Assess interaction patterns of a child with CdCS and parent(s)/caregiver(s). Document positioning that is/is not facilitative to communication, the existence or absence of communication opportunities, and the ability of the parent/caregiver to respond to the child’s communicative signals. Research has shown that children with CdCS demonstrate high levels of distractibility and a low level of object-directed behavior during play(17)Document any feeding difficulties the child has. Children with CdCS often have feeding difficulties and gastroesophageal reflux(3)Document any abnormal muscle function that may affect communication. Children with CdCS often have hypotonia at a young age and then hypertonia as they mature(3)Document any abnormalities in oral motor function, velopharyngeal function, and laryngeal function. The high vocal pitch is most likely due to the malformation of the larynx, which is small, narrow, and diamond shaped. In addition, the epiglottis is small and hypotonic.(3) Patients with CdCS often present with malocclusion, hyper-  and hypotonia, and delayed motor development, all of which may affect oral motor function.(10) In addition, some patients have been noted to have problems with velopharyngeal function.(10) Use informal or formal assessment to record any deficits in oral mechanism form or function and their effect on speech communication –In a descriptive study conducted in Spain with 33 patients (ages 2–35,  average age 14.65) with CdCS, researchers found -Weak sucking ability(18) -Hypotonia of the perioral muscles(18) -Epicanthus (vertical fold of skin on either side of the nose, sometimes covering the inner canthus; i.e., the area where the upper and lower eyelids meet)(18) -Hypertelorism (abnormally increased distance between organs; in this case, the separation typically was noted between the patients’ eyes)(18)  -Short philtrum (the vertical groove in the middle area of the upper lip)(18) -Low-set  ears(18) -Facial asymmetry(18) -Strabism (crossed eyes)(18) -High-arched  palate(18) -Malocclusions -Convex profile with maxillary mandibular retrognathism (abnormal posterior positioning of the jaw bones)(18) -Anterior open bite(18) -Other dental abnormalities (e.g., enamel deficiencies, transposed teeth)(18,33)Document any results of vision examinations. Myopia and cataracts often are reported in patients with CdCS. In addition, vision can be affected by hypersensitivity of the pupil due to a defect of the pupil dilator muscle(3)The absence of functional communication can significantly impact an individual’s ability to participate in activities of daily living. During an assessment, the SLP should consider ways to support a patient’s participation in activities of daily living (e.g., eating, playing, getting dressed). This should be done in collaboration with the patient, family/caregiver, other medical personnel, and school/work staff.(8) Standardized parent interviews of child’s daily living skills (e.g., Vineland Adaptive Behavior Scales) can provide information in a variety of domains(19)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Most children with CdCS present with significant intellectual disability but researchers have indicated that cognitive abilities can range from normal intellectual abilities to severe intellectual deficits.(6) In a study of 26 children with CdCS in the United Kingdom, researchers found that IQ varied from below 40 (n = 4) to between 40 and 57 (n = 22) (mean of 48).(12) The evaluating or treating SLP should note the results of any neurological (MRI, CT), neuropsychological, or psychological/cognitive tests that have been completed. Cognitive abilities, such as attention, perception, memory, reasoning, problem solving, and executive functioning, should also be evaluated.(8) Cognitive testing should be done by a neuropsychologist with experience working with persons with CdCS since IQ tests that depend upon fine motor responses and verbal communication are not valid for this population due to the presence of communication delay and fine and gross motor deficits
relevant tests and measures.swallow examination: Patients with CdCS often have dysphagia and feeding problems in infancy.(18) If the patient and/or caregiver report symptoms of dysphagia, a bedside (or “chairside”) swallowing evaluation (BSE) should be performed by the SLP initially; however, a modified barium swallow study may be required per therapist discretion –For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic
relevant tests and measures.tracheostomy examination: If present, assess tracheostomy tube and document date of placement, current respiratory status, and use of speaking valve. For detailed information on assessment of patients with tracheostomies, see ClinicalChildren with Tracheostomy ; CINAHL Topic ID NumberT709084.For detailed information on assessment of a tracheostomy tube and use of a speaking valve, see Clinical Review…Passy-Muir  Tracheostomy & Ventilator Swallowing and SpeakingT708919

other: To ensure relevance and appropriateness of the treatment program, decisions about goals and course of therapy should be made in collaboration with the patient (if age-appropriate),  the caregivers, other healthcare professionals, and/or educational professionals(26)
Provision of early intervention services can have an impact on later development, and families should be encouraged to seek these services when appropriate(1)
Precautions will vary according to the individual patient and the severity of accompanying language, cognitive, and/or motor symptoms
As with any evaluation, it is important to thoroughly review a patient’s medical records prior to any treatment
A patient and family’s culture and language preference should also be considered to determine the appropriateness of treatment goals, objectives, and materials

Patients who present with gross motor difficulties are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria for inpatients should include fall-prevention  strategies

Patients with CdCS can also have feeding or swallowing difficulties that place them at risk for aspiration. When appropriate, monitor the patient for aspiration and educate the family and caregivers regarding the risks of aspiration and strategies to reduce risk

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis of CdCS is made by a physician based on typical physical characteristics and a karyotype analysis.(3) The need for speech therapy as well as the specific treatment goals will be determined by communication evaluation results and family priorities(7) treatment .
assessment plan of care.rule out: The clinical features of CdCS form a distinct syndrome, allowing for early accurate diagnosis and confirmation by karyotype analysis of blood(3)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: The patient’s family might benefit from services from a genetic counselor to determine the risk of occurrence of CdCS in future offspring. The patient might also receive services from an occupational therapist and physical therapist to assist with gross and fine motor skills. Other specialists should be consulted regarding any physical malformations that interfere with communication (e.g., prosthodontist).(3) A behavioral psychologist may assist with the development of appropriate social behaviors (e.g., play behavior) and the elimination of inappropriate and harmful behaviors(17)
treatment summary: Treatment based on parent priorities:  An analysis of 54 surveys completed by parents to identify educational priorities for their children with CdCS indicated that parent priorities for intervention were not based on the child's strengths but instead, based upon emergent skills and areas of weakness.(7) Most of the nine areas identified as high educational priorities were communication skills: –Personal safety (e.g., awareness of stranger danger) –Toileting  –Ability to describe feelings and events –Ability to follow directions –Ability to respond to questions –Ability to listen to the teacher –Asking for information when needed –Pedestrian safety skills –Ability to express wants and needs

Use of sign language:  Receptive language has been found to be stronger than expressive language for individuals with CdCS; in addition, many individuals (23–50%)  never develop functional oral language.(4) For those individuals who have unintelligible speech, sign language should be explored as a way to support communication. Authors of a case study of two children with CdCS found that the use of both speech and sign language together led to an increase in intelligibility over speech or sign alone. The two children demonstrated some hand-shapes  that deviated from the target hand-shape  in formation of signs; however, their production of signs was consistent(13)

Operant learning principles/graduated guidance: In a multiple baseline study conducted in the United States, researchers examined the effects of a parent-delivered  treatment based upon operant learning principles. One child with CdCS was taught two functional skills: eating and ball rolling.(28) Parent-implemented  procedures included principles of graduated guidance as described by Lovaas.(29) Graduated guidance is a technique involving physical prompting to lead a patient through a series of behaviors to achieve a target behavior. Prompts used in this case study included hand-over-hand guidance, hand-to-elbow  guidance, and a shadow prompt (parents’ hand above the child’s without touching). The last level was a “no prompt” condition. At baseline, the child was unable to demonstrate appropriate ball rolling or eating skills. After treatment, the child showed significant improvements in both tasks, and at 1-year follow-up the child maintained results with 100% accuracy in eating performance (able to eat independently with all meals) and 90% in ball rolling (able to roll ball to mother). Results are promising for the use of operant principles for children with CdCS but preliminary due to the limited evidence of one case study . maintenance or prevention: The child’s communication should be monitored regularly and goals adjusted according to progress
Genetic testing can determine risk of CdCS in future offspring
patient education: Parents of children with rare syndromes are at high risk for stress and depression as compared with parents of children who are typically developing. The SLP can assist by informing the parent about aspects of the syndrome and referring the parent to support groups, social services, and other resources(27) In a study conducted in the United Kingdom investigating the social and medical care experiences of mothers of adults with rare syndromes, researchers identified four major themes:  –The rarity of their offspring's syndrome led to parents' feelings of uncertainty about the prognosis and future. In addition, lack of public awareness of the syndrome led to negative reactions among the public. Because there are no physical features that clearly distinguish a child over the age of 2 with CdCS, the child's behaviors often are misperceived as being deliberately rude –Many mothers received uneven medical and social services due to perceived prejudice against individuals with intellectual disabilities –Mothers expressed frustration at the difficulty in accessing the appropriate social services –Mothers reported that they had to continually advocate for themselves and press for adequate social services
See information series and support group at UK Cri Du Chat Syndrome Support Group Web site: http://criduchat.org.uk/
